author: Ben Rumsby
title: Usain Bolt attempts 'Oscars selfie' with sport's biggest stars as he wins Laureus World Sportsman of the Year for fourth time
text:
Usain Bolt attempts 'Oscars selfie' with sport's biggest stars as he wins Laureus World Sportsman of the Year for fourth time Bolt poses with some of the biggest names in sport Credit: Twitter/@LaureusSport Ben Rumsby 14 February 2017 • 10:40pm 
U sain Bolt was crowned Laureus World Sportsman of the Year for a record-equalling fourth time on Tuesday after ending his Olympic career with another three gold medals . 
The track-and-field legend maintained his record of always being awarded the prize following the Games, beating off competition from Andy Murray, Mo Farah, Cristiano Ronaldo, LeBron James and Stephen Curry at a glittering ceremony in Monte Carlo. 
He celebrated with a post-awards selfie, featuring some of the biggest names in sport including Michael Phelps, Simone Biles, Nico Rosberg. 
Bolt, who plans to retire after this summer’s athletics World Championships in London, added to the titles he won in 2009, 2010 and 2013 to equal Roger Federer’s tally of four Laureus gongs. Bolt beat Mo Farah and Andy Murray among others to the award Credit: EPA 
T he 30-year-old was recognised after becoming the first athlete to win each of the 100 metres, 200m and 4x100m at three successive Olympics, although he was stripped of his 2008 relay title last month after Jamaica team-mate Nesta Carter failed a drugs test. 
Murray and Farah were not the only Britons to miss out on the top prizes after Laura Kenny was beaten to the Sportswoman of the Year gong by gymnastics sensation Simone Biles, who won four gold medals and one bronze at Rio 2016. 
Elaine Thompson, Katie Ledecky, Angelique Kerber and Allyson Felix were the other nominees. 
Leicester City’s 5,000-1 Premier League title triumph was recognised at yet another awards ceremony, with the club handed Laureus’s Spirit of Sport prize. Claudio Ranieri and West Morgan collect their award Credit: EPA 
T hat was after they controversially lost out in the Breakthrough of the Year category to Formula One world champion Nico Rosberg, having not even been nominated for the Team of the Year gong. 
That award went to the Chicago Cubs, who were the other great sports story of 2016. 
Michael Phelps predictably walked away with the Comeback of the Year trophy for his history-making return to the Olympics. He was picked ahead of Britain’s Nick Skelton, whose Rio 2016 show jumping triumph ended his quarter-of-a-century wait for gold. 
The one Briton recognised was downhill mountain bike champions Rachel Atherton, who was named Action Sportsperson of the Year. Follow Telegraph Sport
